"What dire misfortune hovers o'er my head?</br>Why hangs the salt dew on my aching eye?</br>Why doth my bosom pant, so sad, so sore,</br>That was full blithe before?—</br>Bitter occasion prompts th' untimely sigh;</br>Why am I punish'd thus, ye angels!  why?</br>A shepherd swain like me,  of harmless guise,</br>Whose sole amusement was to feed his kine,</br>And tune his oaten pipe the livelong day,—</br>Could he in aught offend th' avenging skies,</br>Or wake the red-wing'd thunderbolt divine?</br>Ah!  no:  of simple structure was his lay;</br>Yet unprofan'd with trick of city art,</br>Pure from the head, and glowing from the heart.—</br>Thou dear memorial of a brother's love,</br>Sweet flute, once warbled to the list'ning grove,</br>And master'd by his skilful hand,</br>How shall I now command</br>The hidden charms that lurk within thy frame,</br>Or tell his gentle fame?</br>Yet will I hail, unmeet, his star-crown'd shade;</br>And beck his rural friends, a tuneful throng,</br>To mend the uncouth lay, and join the rising song.</br>Ah!  I remember well yon oaken arbour gay,</br>Where frequent at the purple dawn of morn,</br>Or 'neath the beetling brow of twilight grey,</br>We sate, like roses twain upon one thorn,</br>Telling romantic tales, of descant quaint,</br>Tinted in various hues with fancy's paint:</br>And I would hearken, greedy of his sound,</br>Lapt in the bosom of soft ecstacy,</br>Till, lifting mildly high</br>Her modest frontlet from the clouds around,</br>Silence beheld us bruise the closing flow'rs,</br>Meanwhile she shed her pure ambrosial show'rs.

"O Shannon!  thy embroider'd banks can tell</br>How oft we stray'd beside thy amber wave,</br>With osier rods arching thy wizard stream,</br>Or weaving garlands for thy liquid brow.</br>Ah me!  my dearest partner seeks the grave;</br>The ruthless grave, extinguisher of joy.</br>Fond Corydon, scarce ripen'd into boy,</br>Where shall I ever find thy pleasing peer?</br>My task is now (ungrateful task, I ween!)</br>To cull the choicest offspring of the year,</br>With myrtles mix'd, and laurels varnish'd bright;</br>And, scatt'ring o'er thy hillock green</br>The poor meed, greet the gloom of night.

"Ye healing Pow'rs, that range the velvet mead,</br>Exhaling the fresh breeze from Zephyr's bow'r,</br>Oh!  where, in that unhappy hour,</br>Where did you fly from his neglected head?</br>Health, thou mountain maid of sprightliest cheek,</br>Ah!  why not cool his forehead meek?</br>Why not in his blest cause thy pow'r display,</br>And chase the fell disorder far away?</br>For he erewhile, most lovely of thy train,</br>Wont the entangled wood to trace,</br>Would hear the jocund horn, and join the chase:</br>Till thou relinquish'd him to grief and pain,</br>E'en in the bloom of flourishing age;</br>And Death, grim tyrant, from his plague-drawn car</br>Espied the horrid Fury's ruthless rage,</br>Then wing'd his ebon shaft, and stopp'd the ling'ring war.

"Yet cease to weep, ye swains; for if no cloud</br>Of thwarting influence mar my keener sight,</br>I mark'd a stranger-star, serenely bright,</br>Burst from the dim inclosure of a shrowd.</br>'Twas Corydon!  a radiant circlet bound</br>His brow of meekness; and the silver sound,</br>Shook from his lyre, of gratulations loud,</br>Smooth'd the unruffled raven-plume of Night."—

Thus chanted the rude youth his  past'ral strain,</br>While the cold earth his playmate's bosom press'd.</br>And now the sun, slow westing to the main,</br>Panted to give his wearied coursers rest;</br>The azure curtains took a crimson stain,</br>And Thetis shone, in golden garments drest.</br>The shepherd-minstrel bent his homeward way,</br>And brush'd the dew-drops from the glitt'ring spray.</br>
